Utterance: <sync>
Hi! It’s good to see you again. How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie. I’ve been okay. I finally sent that message to my family.
That’s a big step! How did it feel to finally send it?
It was a relief, but I’m also really anxious about their response.
It’s completely normal to feel anxious after reaching out. Have you heard back from them yet?
Not yet. I’m trying to stay patient, but it’s hard.
It is tough to wait for a response. Try to focus on the fact that you took a brave step towards healing. How have you been coping with the anxiety in the meantime?
I’ve been keeping busy with writing and doing my mindfulness exercises.
That’s great to hear! Writing can be a wonderful outlet. What have you been working on in your writing?
I’ve been exploring the themes of connection and isolation in my novel. It feels relevant to what I’m experiencing.
That’s a powerful theme. It sounds like you’re really channeling your experiences into your work. How does it feel to write about those themes?
It’s cathartic, but sometimes it makes me feel more vulnerable.
Vulnerability can be uncomfortable, but it often leads to deeper insights. Have you found any ways to manage those feelings while writing?
I try to remind myself that it’s part of the process and that it’s okay to feel uncomfortable.
That’s a healthy perspective. Acknowledging your feelings can help you process them. Now, let’s talk about your job search. Have you made any progress there?
I’ve applied to a few more jobs and followed up with some contacts. No responses yet, though.
It can be disheartening, but persistence is key. How do you feel about the job search process right now?
I’m feeling a bit defeated. It’s hard not to take the lack of responses personally.
It’s understandable to feel that way. Remember that the job market can be unpredictable, and it often has nothing to do with your worth.
Yeah, I know. I just need to keep reminding myself of that.
That’s a good strategy. Have you thought about exploring new avenues, like freelance work or volunteering?
I haven’t, but that could be a good way to gain experience and keep my skills sharp.
Absolutely! It could also help you build connections and potentially lead to job opportunities. What do you think?
I think I’ll look into it. It might take some pressure off the job search too.
That sounds like a positive plan. Now, let’s revisit the topic of your past relationships. What are you feeling about that right now?
I’ve been reflecting a lot on my last relationship and how it ended. I still feel a lot of guilt about it.
It’s common to carry guilt from past relationships. What specific feelings come up for you when you think about it?
I feel like I let her down and that I could have done more to make things work.
It’s important to recognize that relationships are complex, and it takes two people to make them work. What do you think contributed to the challenges in that relationship?
I think my mental health issues played a big role. I wasn’t in a good place, and I didn’t communicate that well.
That’s an important insight. It sounds like you’re recognizing the impact of your mental health on your relationships. How can you use that knowledge moving forward?
I guess I need to be more open about my struggles in future relationships.
That’s a valuable realization. Open communication can lead to healthier connections. How do you feel about dating again in the future?
I’m not sure. I want to, but I worry about repeating the same mistakes.
It’s normal to have those concerns. Perhaps taking the time to focus on yourself and your growth can help you feel more prepared when the time comes.
Yeah, that makes sense. I need to work on being comfortable with myself first.
Absolutely! Focusing on self-growth can lead to healthier relationships in the future. Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
I think that covers it for now. I just want to keep moving forward.
That’s a great mindset. Remember, progress takes time, and you’re doing well. I look forward to our next session.
Thanks, Ellie. I appreciate your support.
You’re welcome! Take care, and see you next time.
Bye!
